questions.question_text_1:
Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions.

The dog was sleeping nearby. He was stirred by the smell of food. He got up, came out of his shelter and stood before the blind man, wagging his tail and gazing expectantly at the bowl, as he was eating his sparse meal. The blind man swept his arms about and asked, 'Who is there?' at which the dog went up and licked his hand. The blind man stroked its coat gently tail to ear and said, 'What a beauty you are. Come with me—' He threw a handful of food, which the dog ate gratefully. It was perhaps an auspicious moment for starting a friendship. They met every day there, and the dog cut off much of its rambling to sit up beside the blind man and watch him receive alms morning to evening. In course of time, observing him, the dog understood that the passers-by must give a coin, and whoever went away without dropping a coin was chased by the dog; he tugged the edge of their clothes by his teeth and pulled them back to the old man at the gate and let go only after something was dropped in his bowl. Among those who frequented this place was a village urchin, who had the mischief of a devil in him. He liked to tease the blind man by calling him names and by trying to pick up the coins in his bowl. The blind man helplessly shouted and cried and whirled his staff. On Thursdays this boy appeared at the gate, carrying on his head a basket loaded with cucumber or plantain. Every Thursday afternoon it was a crisis in the blind man's life. A seller of bright-coloured but doubtful perfumes with his wares mounted on a wheeled platform, a man who spread out cheap storybooks on a gunny sack, another man who carried coloured ribbons on an elaborate frame—these were the people who usually gathered under the same arch. On a Thursday when the young man appeared at the eastern gate one of them remarked, 'Blind fellow! Here comes your scourge—'  
Extract from: The Malgudi Days by R.K. Narayan

Among those who frequented this place was a village urchin, who had the mischief of a devil in him. He liked to tease the blind man by calling him names and by trying to pick up the coins in his bowl. The blind man helplessly shouted and cried and whirled his staff. On Thursdays this boy appeared at the gate, carrying on his head a basket loaded with cucumber or plantain. Every Thursday afternoon it was a crisis in the blind man's life. questions.question_text_1: Read the following exchange between an interviewer and an interviewee and answer the given subquestions: Candidate: Good morning (Smiles at the interview panel.) Interviewer 1: Good morning. _____ Candidate: Yes, sir. Siddhant Arora. Interviewer 2: Please have a seat, Mr. Arora. Candidate: Thank you, sir. (The candidate calmly takes his seat; he carries his certificates, testimonials, etc., in a well-organised folder which he places on the left side of his table.) (Interviewer 1 seems to whisper something to Interviewer 2, and they share a laugh while looking at the candidate. The candidate feels embarrassed, but hides his awkwardness and remains pleasant, but unaffected. The interviewers study him intently.) Interviewer 1: Mr. Arora, where do you come from? Candidate: I come from Uttar Pradesh, sir. Interviewer 1: From where in UP do you hail? Candidate: My hometown is Allahabad, sir. Interviewer 1: _____ Candidate: Sir, Prayag is the same as Allahabad; Prayag was the ancient name of the city. Interviewer 1: Indeed. Can you tell us a little about your educational background? Candidate: I did my primary education from Tagore Public School, Allahabad, and then went on to do my bachelor’s degree in English Language and Literature from the University of Delhi. I did my post-graduation in Human Resource Management from IIM Bangalore. _____ Interviewer 2: A Market Strategy Associate? Your career trajectory appears rather peculiar. _____ It is a strangely slavish choice, don’t you think, to learn something that may well be taken as a sign of colonial oppression? Candidate: (Mildly puzzled for a moment, but quickly regains his composure) Sir, strategization, in the context of a multinational company that offers its services to a substantial and diversified client base, is as much a task of communication as it is one of ideation. English is no longer the language of a particular country or a people. Although we can trace it back to our nation’s colonial past, we can rest assured that it is a language that we have made our own. We leverage English and capitalise on it during our interactions with other international players and markets. Learning literature also impacts the manner in which one thinks because it puts one in intimate contact with some of the best thoughts and creations of humankind. One constantly learns from and draws from a large reservoir of experiences as made available through literature so as to be able to keenly understand the people that one works with, to optimally harness the strengths of those in one’s team and to comprehend and respond to clients’ expectations. My position also requires me to analyse and interpret large amounts of data and have a strong command over various analytical tools. _____ So, different as my qualifications might be, I do believe that they both equally contribute to the manner in which I dispense my duties as a Market Strategy Associate. Interviewer 1: Well put, Mr. Arora. Can you tell us about an experience where you had to collaborate with others because the project at hand required an expertise which you did not have? Candidate: Certainly, sir. What comes to my mind immediately is an instance when I needed legal consultation concerning corporate law both in our country and in the different sites where our client had established operations. _____ He also helped me negotiate transaction documentation and coordinated with external legal counsels. Interviewer 1: Very well, Mr. Arora. _____ Candidate: Sir, I love to read and to go for walks. I also like to follow the latest news in astronomy with an amateurish interest (smiles). Interviewer 2: Astronomy? Candidate: Yes, sir. Like the James Webb Space Telescope’s recent discovery of enormous mature galaxies in its deep field images. Interviewer 2: I see. Interesting (smiles). Interviewer 1: That will be all for now, Mr. Arora. _____ Have a good day. Candidate: Thank you, sir. Wish you a good day ahead too. (Exits after righting the position of the chair that he has vacated.)

Candidate: I did my primary education from Tagore Public School, Allahabad, and then went on to do my bachelor’s degree in English Language and Literature from the University of Delhi. I did my post-graduation in Human Resource Management from IIM Bangalore. _____ Interviewer 2: A Market Strategy Associate? Your career trajectory appears rather peculiar. _____ It is a strangely slavish choice, don’t you think, to learn something that may well be taken as a sign of colonial oppression? Candidate: (Mildly puzzled for a moment, but quickly regains his composure) Sir, strategization, in the context of a multinational company that offers its services to a substantial and diversified client base, is as much a task of communication as it is one of ideation. English is no longer the language of a particular country or a people. Although we can trace it back to our nation’s colonial past, we can rest assured that it is a language that we have made our own. We leverage English and capitalise on it during our interactions with other international players and markets. Learning literature also impacts the manner in which one thinks because it puts one in intimate contact with some of the best thoughts and creations of humankind. One constantly learns from and draws from a large reservoir of experiences as made available through literature so as to be able to keenly understand the people that one works with, to optimally harness the strengths of those in one’s team and to comprehend and respond to clients’ expectations. My position also requires me to analyse and interpret large amounts of data and have a strong command over various analytical tools. _____ So, different as my qualifications might be, I do believe that they both equally contribute to the manner in which I dispense my duties as a Market Strategy Associate. (Exits after righting the position of the chair that he has vacated.)

parent_question.question_text_1: Read the following exchange between an interviewer and an interviewee and answer the given subquestions: Candidate: Good morning (Smiles at the interview panel.) Interviewer 1: Good morning. _____ Candidate: Yes, sir. Siddhant Arora. Interviewer 2: Please have a seat, Mr. Arora. Candidate: Thank you, sir. (The candidate calmly takes his seat; he carries his certificates, testimonials, etc., in a well-organised folder which he places on the left side of his table.) (Interviewer 1 seems to whisper something to Interviewer 2, and they share a laugh while looking at the candidate. The candidate feels embarrassed, but hides his awkwardness and remains pleasant, but unaffected. The interviewers study him intently.) Interviewer 1: Mr. Arora, where do you come from? Candidate: I come from Uttar Pradesh, sir. Interviewer 1: From where in UP do you hail? Candidate: My hometown is Allahabad, sir. Interviewer 1: _____ Candidate: Sir, Prayag is the same as Allahabad; Prayag was the ancient name of the city. Interviewer 1: Indeed. Can you tell us a little about your educational background? Candidate: I did my primary education from Tagore Public School, Allahabad, and then went on to do my bachelor’s degree in English Language and Literature from the University of Delhi. I did my post-graduation in Human Resource Management from IIM Bangalore. _____ Interviewer 2: A Market Strategy Associate? Your career trajectory appears rather peculiar. _____ It is a strangely slavish choice, don’t you think, to learn something that may well be taken as a sign of colonial oppression? Candidate: (Mildly puzzled for a moment, but quickly regains his composure) Sir, strategization, in the context of a multinational company that offers its services to a substantial and diversified client base, is as much a task of communication as it is one of ideation. English is no longer the language of a particular country or a people. Although we can trace it back to our nation’s colonial past, we can rest assured that it is a language that we have made our own. We leverage English and capitalise on it during our interactions with other international players and markets. Learning literature also impacts the manner in which one thinks because it puts one in intimate contact with some of the best thoughts and creations of humankind. One constantly learns from and draws from a large reservoir of experiences as made available through literature so as to be able to keenly understand the people that one works with, to optimally harness the strengths of those in one’s team and to comprehend and respond to clients’ expectations. My position also requires me to analyse and interpret large amounts of data and have a strong command over various analytical tools. _____ So, different as my qualifications might be, I do believe that they both equally contribute to the manner in which I dispense my duties as a Market Strategy Associate. Interviewer 1: Well put, Mr. Arora. Can you tell us about an experience where you had to collaborate with others because the project at hand required an expertise which you did not have? Candidate: Certainly, sir. What comes to my mind immediately is an instance when I needed legal consultation concerning corporate law both in our country and in the different sites where our client had established operations. _____ He also helped me negotiate transaction documentation and coordinated with external legal counsels. Interviewer 1: Very well, Mr. Arora. _____ Candidate: Sir, I love to read and to go for walks. I also like to follow the latest news in astronomy with an amateurish interest (smiles). Interviewer 2: Astronomy? Candidate: Yes, sir. Like the James Webb Space Telescope’s recent discovery of enormous mature galaxies in its deep field images. Interviewer 2: I see. Interesting (smiles). Interviewer 1: That will be all for now, Mr. Arora. _____ Have a good day. Candidate: Thank you, sir. Wish you a good day ahead too. (Exits after righting the position of the chair that he has vacated.)

(ii) _____ Clerk: As to G.S.15A-2000 murder in the first degree, what is the jury’s verdict? Foreperson (reads): We, the jury, find the defendant, Catherine Danielle Clark, not guilty of first-degree murder of Mr. Chase Andrews. Clerk: Members of the jury, your foreperson has announced the following verdict: G.S.15A-2000, murder in the first degree, not guilty. (iii) _____ Jurors (collectively): Yes Judge: If anyone said no, please raise your hand. (Nobody raises their hand.) Judge: Do you wish the jury to be polled? (No party makes an application for a poll.) Judge: (iv) _____ Ms. Clark, you are free to go, and I apologize on behalf of the State for the time that you have served. The jury is hereby discharged from the case. (v) _____ Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

(ii) _____ Clerk: As to G.S.15A-2000 murder in the first degree, what is the jury’s verdict? Foreperson (reads): We, the jury, find the defendant, Catherine Danielle Clark, not guilty of first-degree murder of Mr. Chase Andrews. Clerk: Members of the jury, your foreperson has announced the following verdict: G.S.15A-2000, murder in the first degree, not guilty. (iii) _____ Jurors (collectively): Yes Judge: If anyone said no, please raise your hand. (Nobody raises their hand.) Judge: Do you wish the jury to be polled? (No party makes an application for a poll.) Judge: (iv) _____ Ms. Clark, you are free to go, and I apologize on behalf of the State for the time that you have served. The jury is hereby discharged from the case. (v) _____ Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **English II (Computer-Based Exam)** based on the provided question paper. The exam focuses on **comprehension, grammar, vocabulary, communication skills, and critical reasoning**. Below is a breakdown of key areas: --- ### **1. Reading Comprehension** #### **Core Concepts:** - **Literal Comprehension**: Extract explicit details (e.g., "What stirred the dog from sleep?" → *Smell of food*). - **Inferential Comprehension**: Derive implicit meanings (e.g., "Why did the dog chase passers-by?" → *To ensure coins were dropped for the blind man*). - **Vocabulary in Context**: Understand words/phrases based on surrounding text (e.g., "tugged" → antonym: *pushed*). - **Character Analysis**: Identify traits/motivations (e.g., "village urchin" → *mischievous*). - **Tone and Mood**: Recognize emotional undertones (e.g., blind man’s *helplessness* when teased). #### **Key Passages:** - **Excerpt from *Malgudi Days* by R.K. Narayan**: - Themes: **Friendship**, **compassion**, **survival**, **exploitation**. - Characters: Blind man, dog, village urchin, merchants. - Plot: Dog helps blind man collect alms; conflict with a troublemaker. #### **Strategies:** - Skim for **main ideas**, then scan for **specific details**. - Note **chronological events** (e.g., dog’s behavior progression). - Pay attention to **dialogue** (e.g., blind man’s reactions). --- ### **2. Grammar and Syntax** #### **Core Topics:** | **Topic** | **Key Rules/Examples** | **Question Types** | |-------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------| | **Tenses** | - Simple Past: *She **fasted** for a day.*
- Present Perfect: *She **has fasted** before.* | Fill-in-the-blanks, error correction. | | **Conditionals** | - **Third Conditional**: *If they had left early, they **wouldn’t have missed** the train.* | Identify sentence type. | | **Direct/Indirect Speech** | - Direct: *"What time does the train leave?" he asked.*
- Indirect: *He asked what time the train left.* | Convert between direct/indirect speech. | | **Modals** | - **Politeness**: *Would you mind if I stayed?*
- **Permission**: *Could I leave early?* | Fill-in-the-blanks. | | **Articles/Determiners**| - *Many/Much/Enough*: *Do we have **enough** bread?*
- *Too many/many*: *Were there **many** students?* | Choose correct determiner. | | **Prepositions** | - *Since/For*: *They’ve lived here **since** 2020.* | Fill-in-the-blanks. | | **Conjunctions** | - **Contrast**: *although, despite, in spite of*. | Choose correct conjunction. | | **Participles** | - *Scratched denims* (**past participle** as adjective). | Identify the participle. | | **Passive Voice** | - *The championship **was won** by Ferrari.* | Convert active → passive. | | **Suffixes/Prefixes** | - *-vore* (feeding), *mega-* (big), *-cide* (killing). | Match meanings. | #### **Common Errors to Avoid:** - **Subject-Verb Agreement**: *She don’t* → **She doesn’t**. - **Double Negatives**: *She didn’t do nothing* → **She didn’t do anything**. - **Misplaced Modifiers**: *Almost every student passed* (correct) vs. *Every student almost passed* (ambiguous). --- ### **3. Vocabulary** #### **Key Areas:** - **Antonyms/Synonyms**: - *Tugged* (pulled) ↔ *Pushed*. - *Sparse* (meager) ≈ *scant*. - **Idioms/Expressions**: - *Against all odds* = despite difficulties. - *Waste something on someone* = something is not appreciated by the recipient. - **Literary Devices**: - **Oxymoron**: *Deafening silence* (not *"youth is wasted on the young"* → that’s **paradox**). - **Adjectival Clauses**: *The team, **led by their captain**, won.* (modifies *team*). - **Word Forms**: - *Bona fide* = authentic (Latin origin). - *Allegedly* = claimed without proof (sentence adverb for speaker’s attitude). #### **Strategies:** - Use **context clues** for unfamiliar words. - Break down **roots/affixes** (e.g., *ultra-* = excess, *-gamy* = marriage). --- ### **4. Communication Skills** #### **Core Concepts:** - **Formal vs. Informal Language**: - **Email Etiquette**: - **Subject Line**: Clear and specific (*"Acceptance of Job Offer"*). - **Salutation**: *Dear Sir/Ma’am* (not *Hey*). - **Closing**: *Warm regards* (professional). - **Interview Skills**: - **Body Language**: Organized folder, maintaining composure. - **Handling Pressure**: Staying pleasant despite interviewers’ laughter (*intimidation tactic*). - **STAR Method** for behavioral questions: - **Situation**, **Task**, **Action**, **Result** (e.g., legal consultation example). - **Dialogue Completion**: - **Courtroom Language**: Formal, precise (*"We have, Your Honor"*). - **Politeness**: *Would you mind...* (not *Could you...*). #### **Key Scenarios:** | **Scenario** | **Appropriate Response** | |-------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Job Interview** | - Explain how skills apply to role.
- Stay calm under pressure. | | **Email Writing** | - Professional tone.
- Correct subject line/salutation. | | **Courtroom Dialogue** | - Formal phrases (*"The jury upholds its verdict"*). | | **Handling Criticism** | - Defend choices logically (e.g., *English literature’s relevance in business*). | --- ### **5. Critical Reasoning** #### **Core Skills:** - **Deduction**: Infer questions from answers (e.g., *"How did your degree help?"* → Answer about communication/ideation). - **Logical Flow**: Fill blanks in dialogues/emails contextually. - **True/False Analysis**: Verify statements against given text (e.g., *Alice Walker’s job title*). - **Matching**: Pair prefixes/suffixes with meanings (e.g., *-cide* = killing). #### **Example Questions:** 1. **Deduce the Question**: - Answer: *"Prayag is the same as Allahabad."* - Question: *"Do you know where Prayag is located?"* 2. **Fill in the Blank**: - *"I love to read and go for walks."* → Question: *"What do you do in your spare time?"* 3. **Identify Tone**: - *"Strangely slavish choice"* → **Provocative** (not placatory). --- ### **6. Literary and Cultural Knowledge** #### **Key References:** - **Authors/Works**: - *Malgudi Days* by **R.K. Narayan** (Indian English literature). - **James Webb Space Telescope** (astronomy, for interview context). - **Cultural Context**: - **Colonialism**: English as a "colonial oppression" vs. global communication tool. - **Legal Terms**: *Polling the jury*, *verdict upholding*. --- ### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** #### **Graph 1: Reading Comprehension Relationships** ```mermaid graph TD A[Passage: Malgudi Days] --> B[Characters] A --> C[Themes] A --> D[Plot Events] B --> B1[Blind Man] B --> B2[Dog] B --> B3[Village Urchin] B --> B4[Merchants] C --> C1[Friendship] C --> C2[Survival] C --> C3[Exploitation] D --> D1[Dog Wakes Up] D --> D2[Helps Blind Man] D --> D3[Conflict with Urchin] D --> D4[Thursday Crisis] B1 --> D2 B2 --> D1 B3 --> D3 ``` #### **Graph 2: Grammar Topics Hierarchy** ```mermaid graph TD A[Grammar] --> B[Tenses] A --> C[Conditionals] A --> D[Speech] A --> E[Modals] A --> F[Determiners] B --> B1[Simple Past] B --> B2[Present Perfect] C --> C1[Zero Conditional] C --> C2[Third Conditional] D --> D1[Direct] D --> D2[Indirect] E --> E1[Politeness: Would] E --> E2[Permission: Could] F --> F1[Many/Much] F --> F2[Enough/Too] ``` #### **Graph 3: Interview Skills Flow** ```mermaid graph LR A[Greeting] --> B[Introduction] B --> C[Background Questions] C --> D[Behavioral Questions] D --> E[Situational Questions] E --> F[Closing] C --> C1[Education] C --> C2[Experience] D --> D1[STAR Method] D --> D2[Handling Pressure] F --> F1[Follow-Up] F --> F2[Professional Exit] ``` #### **Graph 4: Email Writing Components** ```mermaid graph TD A[Email Structure] --> B[Subject Line] A --> C[Salutation] A --> D[Body] A --> E[Closing] B --> B1[Clear/Purposeful] C --> C1[Formal: Dear Sir] D --> D1[Concise] D --> D2[Polite Tone] E --> E1[Warm Regards] E --> E2[Signature] ``` --- ### **Exam Strategies** 1. **Time Management**: - Spend **~1 min per question** for comprehension/grammar. - Allocate **2-3 mins** for email/dialogue completion. 2. **Process of Elimination**: - Rule out **obviously wrong options** first (e.g., *"Hey Ma’am"* in a formal email). 3. **Contextual Clues**: - For vocabulary, use **surrounding sentences** to infer meaning. 4. **Review**: - Flag **uncertain questions** and return if time permits. 5. **Practice**: - **Mock tests** for speed. - **Flashcards** for vocabulary/prefixes-suffixes.
